coredata.dc:title: Physicochemically dendrite-suppressed three-dimensional fluoridation solid-state electrolyte for high-rate lithium metal battery
coredata.dc:creator: Xu, Zhong
Zhang, Haitao
Yang, Tao
Chu, Xiang
Xie, Yanting
Wang, Qungui
Xia, Yuanhua
Yang, Weiqing
coredata.dc:description: Naturally structural and chemical interface instability between solid-state electrolyte (SSE) and Li anode is still a bottleneck for the suppression of Li dendrites to date. Herein, we design the 3D in situ-fluorinated perovskite-type electrolyte hybridized with poly (ethylene oxide) fibers (F-LLTO@PEO) for the synergistically enhanced physicochemical-interface stability. The rapidly Li-ions-transporting and high shear modulus 3D skeleton-structured SSE can physically suppress Li dendrite growth, while the LiF-rich solid-state electrolyte interface (SEI) layer of the in situ fluoridated SSE can chemically eliminate the security risk of Li dendrites. This unique SSE exhibits a high ionic conductivity of 5 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 25°C. Based on the above, the as-developed solid-state lithium metal batteries (SSLMBs) possess excellent rate-capability of 95 mAh g−1 @ 5 C and cycling stability over 80% after 100 cycles at 90°C. Evidently, this physicochemically dendrite-suppressed strategy will open a previously unexplored opportunity in developing safe, high-performance SSLMBs.

3D F-LLTO@PEO SSE for high-rate solid-state lithium metal battery applications

(B) 3D F-LLTO facilitates rapid Li+ diffusion pathway.
(C) 3D F-LLTO@PEO networks prepared from electrospun F-LLTO precursor and PVP skeleton, heat-treatment, and solution casting processes.
(D) crystal structures of LLTO and F-LLTO through configuration optimization.
(E) 3D LLTO@PEO solid-state electrolytes provide physico-chemical dual protection to realize dendrite-free flexible lithium metal battery.
Fluorinated LLTO ceramics and improved electrochemical properties
(A) DFT configuration optimized F-LLTO and LLTO crystals.
(B) Rietveld refinement XRD spectra of F-LLTO.
(C–D) TEM and high-resolution TEM image of 3D F-LLTO fiber.
(E) Energy band and local density of state of F-LLTO calculated from DFT computation.
(F) Temperature-dependence ionic conductivity of F-LLTO@PEO and F-free-LLTO SSEs.
(G) Liner sweep voltammograms of F-LLTO@PEO SSEs at different temperatures.
(H) DC polarization results for Li/F-LLTO@PEO/Li symmetrical battery at 10 mV S−1 (the inset exhibits EIS plots before and after polarization).
(I) Cycling stability of F-LLTO@PEO and F-free-LLTO@PEO SSEs at different current densities.
Morphology and thermal properties of 3D F-LLTO@PEO networks
(A) Schematic illustration of 3D F-LLTO networks.
(B) SEM images of different processed 3D F-LLTO networks.
(C) The corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) elemental mapping of F, Ti, La and O distribution.
(D) The diameter distribution and average diameter of 3D F-LLTO nanofibers.
(E) Thermal stability operated at 25°C, 60°C, 90°C and 150°C for 1 h on the SSEs and celgard 2400.
(F) Thermogravimetric analysis of F-LLTO@PEO, F-free-LLTO@PEO and pure PEO.
3D F-LLTO@PEO SSEs enabling highly stable all-solid-state Li/LFP metal battery
(A) Charge/discharge profiles of Li/SSEs/LFP cells at various current rates from 0.1 to 5C (1C = 170 mAh g−1).
(B) Rate capability of Li/SSEs/LFP cells at various current rates from 0.1 to 5C.
(C) Charge/discharge profiles of Li/SSEs/LFP cells after 1, 10, 50 and 100 cycles, respectively.
(D) Long-term cycling stability of the Li/SSEs/LFP cells with a potential range of 2.5−4.3 V at a current rate of 0.5C and corresponding Coulombic efficiency.
(E) Schematically illustrating the internal structure of high-safety soft-package all-solid-state Li/SSEs/LFP batteries.
(F) The OCV test of a typical as-obtained battery.

(G) Cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of soft-package Li/SSEs/LFP batteries at a scanning rate of 0.05 mV s−1. (H1−H8) Working states of soft-package batteries under various harsh conditions such as cutting, folding, and perforation.
Disclosing physicochemical protection mechanism
(A) Schematic illustration of the dual effects. Ex-situ F 1 s XPS spectra of the cycled
(B) F-LLTO@PEO SSEs and

head.ce:title: Physicochemically dendrite-suppressed three-dimensional fluoridation solid-state electrolyte for high-rate lithium metal battery

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Naturally structural and chemical interface instability between solid-state electrolyte (SSE) and Li anode is still a bottleneck for the suppression of Li dendrites to date. Herein, we design the 3D in situ-fluorinated perovskite-type electrolyte hybridized with poly (ethylene oxide) fibers (F-LLTO@PEO) for the synergistically enhanced physicochemical-interface stability. The rapidly Li-ions-transporting and high shear modulus 3D skeleton-structured SSE can physically suppress Li dendrite growth, while the LiF-rich solid-state electrolyte interface (SEI) layer of the in situ fluoridated SSE can chemically eliminate the security risk of Li dendrites. This unique SSE exhibits a high ionic conductivity of 5 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 25°C. Based on the above, the as-developed solid-state lithium metal batteries (SSLMBs) possess excellent rate-capability of 95 mAh g−1 @ 5 C and cycling stability over 80% after 100 cycles at 90°C. Evidently, this physicochemically dendrite-suppressed strategy will open a previously unexplored opportunity in developing safe, high-performance SSLMBs.

By in situ doping fluoridate atoms into perovskite solid-state electrolyte, Xu et al. develop a physicochemically dendrite-suppressed strategy to effectively engineer the solid-state electrolyte with 3D in situ fluorinated structure. It is an efficient ubiquitous method to rationally modulate SSEs to realize the desired Li anode protection.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: All the necessary data supporting the main findings of the paper are available within the main paper and its Supplemental information files and from the Lead Contact upon reasonable request.

ce:section.ce:para: Recently, the sharply growing demand for higher energy density and safety lithium metal battery (LMB) has greatly motivated the rapid development of solid-state electrolytes (SSEs). 1–8 These SSEs can ensure the safe application of Li-anodes due to their excellent thermostability, wide electrochemical stable window (EW), superior Li-ionic conductivity, high elastic modulus and environmental friendliness. 9–11 However, the practical applications of SSEs in LMBs still have been hindered by notable challenges. One of the primary issues is that the intrinsically sluggish Li+ diffusion kinetics in SSEs would lead to a low room temperature ionic conductivity, the decreasing Coulombic efficiency (CE) and capacity failure of LMBs. 12–14 Another major problem is that the repeated Li+ plating and stripping on Li anode could induce nucleation and growth of dendritic projections during high-rate cycling. 15 Efforts from historical and theoretical works have proved that increasing electrolyte stiffening and transport numbers are the keys for dendrite mitigation. 16–19

In this regard, the interface engineering of SSEs provides excellent strategies for the effective settlement of electrolyte stiffening and transport numbers, such as artificial SEI film, 3D interfacial structure, as well as chemical modifications. 20–23 For instance, Goodenough et al. 24 designed a chemically modified garnet SSE (Li7La3Zr2O12, LLZO) to completely remove the Li2CO3 from LLZO surface and show the excellent wettability at Li anode interface. Additionally, Fan and co-workers 25 demonstrated the mechanically enhanced PI-LLZTO/PVDF SSEs for physically stabilized Li metal anodes. Although these approaches could physically or chemically improve the interfacial wettability and thus reduce Li dendrite propagation to some extent, Li dendrites would still occur under high current density or extended cycling time. Conceptually, the physicochemical strategy could complement each other for the structurally and chemically enhanced SSE and SEI layer. Actually, to realize a physicochemically dendrite-suppressed strategy is a big challenge to construct SSE and SEI layers.

In this work, we develop a physicochemically dendrite-suppressed strategy for dendrite-free LMBs through 3D in situ-fluorinated perovskite-type electrolyte hybridized with poly (ethylene oxide) fibers (F-LLTO@PEO) (3D F-LLTO@PEO SSEs). Physically, the rapidly Li+ transporting and high shear modulus 3D skeleton-structured SSE could suppress Li dendrites formation on the Li anode. Chemically, the LiF-rich solid-state electrolyte interface (SEI) layer of the in situ fluoridated SSE could eliminate the security risk of Li dendrites. The mechanical flexibility of the PEO matrix endows the excellent flexibility of LMBs (Figure 1A), and the confinement effect of the 3D F-LLTO nanofibers network effectively promotes the ion-oriented transporting for the settlement of sluggish Li+ diffusion kinetics among SSEs (Figure 1B). As a result, this unique 3D F-LLTO@PEO SSE presents the high ionic conductivity of 5 × 10−4 S cm−1 at room temperature, high-rate capability of 1 mA cm−2 over 200 h, and extraordinarily interfacial stability with Li metal anode (> 1000 h under 0.1 mA cm−2). The SSLMBs based on this SSE would substantially demonstrate the high specific capacity of 152 mAh g−1 @ 0.1 C, excellent rate capacity of 95 mAh g−1 @ 5 C, and cycling capacity retention over 80% after 100 cycles at 90°C. Therefore, this physicochemically dendrite-suppressed strategy will greatly promote the rapid development of safe, high-performance solid-state LMBs.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Chemically dendrite-suppressed mechanism and characterization of 3D F-LLTO@PEO SSE
ce:section.ce:para: As shown in Figure 1C, this 3D F-LLTO@PEO nanofibers network was constructed via electrospinning the F-LLTO precursor and PVP skeleton, followed by self-sacrificing heat-treatment and the PEO solution casting process. The substituent of F element with higher binding energy for O element in the body-centered cubic would form a steady crystal structure of F-LLTO (Figure 1D). On the one hand, the highly physical ductility of flexible PEO matrix and rigid 3D LLTO networks can effectively block the further side reactions between metallic Li and the LLTO electrolyte. On the other hand, the chemically functionalized F elements of the F-LLTO electrolyte would gradually transform into an LiF-rich SEI layer with very low electronic conductivity, high stability and high interfacial energy against the Li anode. 26–28 Besides, the PEO matrix among F-LLTO could efficiently prevent Ti4+ of F-LLTO from directly interacting with the Li anode for superior electrochemical stability. 29 Therefore, this physicochemically dendrite-suppressed strategy in 3D F-LLTO@PEO can effectively facilitate the formation of a dense, uniform SEI layer, suppress irreversible Li+ plating-stripping behavior, and substantially inhibits Li dendrites growing (Figure 1E).

In Figure 2A, the crystal structure of F-LLTO and F-free-LLTO is calculated to be the typical A-site-deficient perovskite (ABO3) by density functional theory (DFT). 30 The La, Ti and Li atoms are regularly distributed on the three crystal planes of LLTO, while the O atoms discretely fill the remaining vacancy. 29 Based on the minimum energy principle (The formation energy of several structures in Figures S1–S3; Table S1), the in situ fluorination replacement of F atoms for O atoms bonding with Li atoms is proved to be the most stable structure of F-LLTO. Experimentally, X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurement and Rietveld refinement using the Maud analysis system can further confirm the crystalline evolution of fluorinated LLTO. 31
Figure S4 displays the XRD patterns of 3D F-LLTO, F-LLTO bulk and F-free-LLTO bulk, respectively, indicating that all the diffraction peaks should be indexed to the standard tetragonal P4/mmm space group (Database: JCPDS#46-0465). 26 Meanwhile, the unnoticeable deviation Swp result by Rietveld refinement evidently proves that the fluorine atom should be successfully incorporated into the LLTO crystal structure 32 (Figure 2B). The cell information details and structure parameters of F-LLTO and F-free-LLTO from Rietveld refinement are shown in Tables S2–S4. The high-resolution neutron diffraction (HRND) of F-LLTO could also confirm this structure (Figure S5). A typical polycrystalline tetragonal structure in the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images and the corresponding selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern could be identified with the XRD patterns (Figures 2C and S6). In Figure 2D, the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of individual 3D LLTO obviously presents the excellent crystallinity within each grain. 33 For further understanding the influence of in situ fluoridation on electronic structure, the energy band (EB) and local density of state (LDOS) of electrons are calculated and the corresponding results are shown in Figures 2E and S7. Generally, the band gap is a descriptor for the intrinsic electrochemical stability window (EW) of solid-state electrolyte materials. 34
,
35 The broader band gap of F-LLTO (2.30 eV) than that F-free-LLTO (2.26 eV) could evidently reveal the higher EW. In addition, the band gap quantified experimentally from a Tauc Plot is 2.338 eV, which is in agreement with the calculated results (Figure S8). Therefore, the in situ fluorination F-LLTO possesses tetragonal perovskite structure, fiber-like microstructure, and predominant electrochemical stability.

After in situ fluoridation, F-LLTO exhibits substantially enhanced electrochemical performance. In comparison with F-free SSE, 3D F-LLTO@PEO SSE delivers significantly improved ionic conductivity throughout the whole temperature range (Figure 2F). Specifically, the ionic conductivity of F-LLTO@PEO SSE (∼5.0 × 10−4 S cm−1) exhibits one order of magnitude higher than that of F-free-LLTO SSE (∼1.2 × 10−4 S cm−1) at RT. The well-fitted AC impedance spectra of SSEs at different temperatures are given in Figure S9. The F-LLTO@PEO obviously exhibits lower interfacial impedance (12.6 Ω) than LLTO@PEO (39.2 Ω). At high and intermediate frequencies, the well-defined semicircle can clearly demonstrate the parallel combination of bulk resistance and bulk capacitance, which are mainly ascribed to the migratability of ions and the immobility of polymer chains. 23 While at low frequencies, the spike can obviously present the double-layer capacitance property at the electrodes-electrolyte interface. 33

Besides, 3D F-LLTO@PEO SSE is equipped with the superior electrochemical stability. In Figures 2G and S10, 3D F-LLTO@PEO can demonstrate excellent stability up to 6 V. But for F-free SSE, the obvious decomposition will arise only at 4.8 V. Such remarkable electrochemical stability of 3D F-LLTO@PEO could make it possible for matching with a high-voltage cathode and then building high energy density SSLMBs. 36 In addition, Lithium transference number (t Li +) of 3D F-LLTO@PEO is 56.25% higher than that of F-free SSE (Figures 2H and S11; Table S6), indicating faster Li+ ion transport kinetics during high-rate cycle. 37
,
38 The FT-IR spectra and the corresponding Gaussian fitting results of pure PEO and F-LLTO@PEO SSEs could also prove that the fluorinated LLTO increases the Li ion (Figures S12 and S13, Table S7). Typically, FT-IR spectra within the range of 600 to approximately 650 cm−1 can directly verify the solvation of LiClO4. In the PEO-LiClO4 SSE systems, the ClO4 − will ether dissociate from LiClO4 (free ClO4 − ∼620 cm−1) or incorporate to a bonded ion pair (bonded ClO4 − ∼635 cm−1). Figure S13 evidently exhibits the Gaussian fitting results of two types of ClO4 − in pure PEO and F-LLTO@PEO SSEs. The F-LLTO@PEO exhibits the higher percentage of free ClO4 − (97.07%) with the highest interaction among PEO, F-LLTO, and LiClO4. These faster Li+ ion-transport kinetics results could be attributed to the defects-induced vacancy conduction mechanism. 39 Generally, the Ti-F Coulomb force is smaller than that of Ti-O, and the Ti-F atomic distance is theoretically greater than the Ti-O atomic distance. Once the F dopant changes the local structure around Ti atoms, the Ti-O(F) atomic distance will gradually increase, which would broaden the bottleneck of TiO(F)6 for declining activation energy of ion transport. 40
,
41 Therefore, 3D F-LLTO@PEO is much easier to achieve higher ionic conductivity and larger lithium transference number than F-free-LLTO@PEO SSE.

Furthermore, in situ-fluoridation protection could greatly increase the critical current density for Li dendrite-suppressed ability. 42
Figure 2I shows the voltage profiles of the two symmetric cells with a step-increased current density. Initially, both cells exhibit a similar increment behavior of overpotential with the increasing current density. The interfacial resistance of both cells moderately increases during the initial cycling period and then keeps steady with time-evolution (Figure S14). This phenomenon implies that a thin and stable Li+ conductive passivation layer should form on the surface of the Li metal anode for the inhibition of further side reaction. However, when the current density reaches to 0.5 mA cm−2, the Li/F-free-LLTO@PEO/Li symmetric cell displays an abnormal overpotential transformation during the charging process, leading to a short circuit in the battery. On the contrary, even at a large current density of 1 mA cm−2, the Li/F-LLTO@PEO/Li cell still presents no obvious voltage drop. Further, the F-LLTO@PEO SSE-based battery presents an excellent stability over 1000 h, while for the F-free-LLTO@PEO SSE-based battery, its lifetime is only 368 h even at the lower current density of 0.1 mA cm−2 (Figure S15).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Physically dendrite-suppressed mechanism and characterization of 3D F-LLTO@PEO SSE
ce:section.ce:para: From Figure 3A, the 3D F-LLTO@PEO SSEs are fabricated through a template self-sacrificing and solution-casting methods. The detailed experimental steps are shown in Figure S16. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images could clearly show a flat PVP skeleton surface and further verify the even dispersion of tetrahedral F-LLTO into the 3D F-LLTO nanofibers (Figure 3B). After the solution-casting process, 3D F-LLTO@PEO SSEs manifest a relatively smooth surface, which is beneficial for the construction of low interfacial impedance all-solid-state LMBs. In addition, the average thickness of 3D F-LLTO@PEO SSEs is about 189 μm (Figure S17 ). Such moderate thickness is useful for promoting fast ion-transportation and avoiding short circuit simultaneously.

As discussed above, the incorporation of fluoridation into the electrolyte is one of the key approaches to prevent the lithium dendrites between the electrolyte and Li anode. To verify the presence of the F element, the energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS) are recorded in detail. The EDS confirms the homogeneous distribution of Ti, La, O, and F atoms in the nanofiber (Figure 3C). Notably, the F atoms evenly distribute in the LLTO skeleton and the approximate doping amount is 1.17 w.t.% (Figure S18; Table S8). The accurate chemical formula of F-LLTO could be confirmed as Li0.33La0.557TiO3-yFy, in which y is approximately 0.045. Figure 3D confirms the average diameter of 3D F-LLTO nanofibers calcined at 850°C is ∼720 nm. The diameter of F-LLTO nanofibers decreases as the calcination temperature increases from 800°C to 900°C (Figure S19), which is due to the grain growth accompanying the occurrence of a coarse surface. For the specific surface area of nanofiber, F-LLTO nanofibers at 850°C are selected as the 3D SSE skeleton for further studying.

Importantly, 3D F-LLTO@PEO membranes reveal eminent resilience and mechanical strength which are essential for SSEs to evaluate processability for alleviating lithium dendrite growth during high-rate cycling. In general, the resilience is attributed to the polymer matrix so that the flexibility will be deteriorated as the content of lithium salts increases. In the case of PEO-LiClO4, it shows a one-step break mechanism of non-liner elastic performance. The molecular arrangement of the polymer chains would be rearranged during the yield period between elastic deformation and plastic deformation. In the 3D F-LLTO@PEO, there was similar behavior, but a longer elongation to break could be observed because of the 3D network skeleton (Figure S20).

Thermal stability and safety of SSEs are another crucial parameter in determining their successful application in SSLMBs. According to high-temperature tolerance testing, 3D F-LLTO@PEO exhibits negligible variation even at 150°C, while the commercial celgard 2400 separator totally collapses at the same temperature (Figure 3E). This result can coincide with the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurements (Figure 3F), where the decomposition of PEO appears from 300°C and loses about 64 w.t% until 580°C. Interestingly, the in situ fluoridation could significantly improve the thermal stability of LLTO@PEO from 300°C to 350°C, which is attributed to higher interaction energy between LiF and LLTO. 43 As such, 3D F-LLTO@PEO SSEs can work steadily over a wide temperature and meet the physicochemical requirements of high-performance SSEs.

ce:section.ce:section-title: 3D F-LLTO@PEO SSE for high-rate solid-state lithium metal battery applications
ce:section.ce:para: Based on 3D F-LLTO@PEO SSE, we further explore high-rate SSLMBs. Solid-state LiFePO4 (LFP) was chosen as the cathode because of its favorable compatibility with the PEO and Li metallic anode. Notably, the LFP-based cathode consisted of 80 w.t% LFP, 10 w.t% conductive carbon black, and 10 w.t% F-LLTO@PEO instead of traditional polymeric binders (such as PVDF) for faster Li+ ion transfer kinetics. The temperature-dependent EIS spectra of Li/SSEs/LFP cells (Figures S21A and S21B) obviously demonstrate that the higher temperature (up to 90°C) would result in lower interfacial resistance and faster electrochemical kinetics. 44 For cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves, a pair of apparent redox peaks located at 3.6 and 3.2 V may correspond to the delithiation/lithiation of the LFP cathode at the initial cycle. Subsequently, both the oxidation and reduction peak intensities slightly increase (Figure S22), indicating the gradually increased reaction kinetics. The gradually decreasing interfacial impedance of Li/F-LLTO@PEO/LFP cell could validate this promoted reaction activity during cycling (Figure S23).

Figure 4A provides the charge/discharge profiles of Li/F-LLTO@PEO/LFP cells at different current rates from 0.1 to 5C (1C = 170 mA g−1). Consistent with CV analysis, the Li/F-LTTO@PEO/LFP cell shows two typical potential plateaus at 3.45 and 3.35 V at 0.1C, corresponding to the Li+ ions extraction/insertion behaviors. Notably, the Li/F-LLTO@PEO/LFP cell delivers a reversible capacity of 152 mAh g−1 at 0.1C and retains high reversible capacities of 145 and 139 mAh g−1 at 1C and 2C, respectively. Even at 5C, the specific discharge capacity could still maintain 97 mAh g−1, representing the remarkable rate capability (Figure 4B). The corresponding energy density is 106.64 Wh kg−1. Such high-rate capability is mainly ascribed to the fast diffusion kinetics of Li+. When the current density returns to 0.1C, the reversible capacity can almost recover its premier value, manifesting respectably stable electrochemical performance of the 3D F-LLTO@PEO SSEs. Figures 4C and 4D display the long-term cycling stability and corresponding Coulombic efficiency of Li/F-LLTO@PEO/LFP cells with a potential range of 2.5-4.3 V at 0.5C. The Li/F-LLTO@PEO/LFP cell maintains a reversible capacity of 123 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.5C rate with an average Coulombic efficiency of over 99%, while the Li/F-free-LLTO@PEO/LFP cell only holds a reversible capacity of 92 mAh g−1. A more detailed comparison between our 3D F-LLTO SSE and the state-of-the-art PEO-based SSEs further sheds light on the comprehensive advantages of our 3D F-LLTO SSEs (Table S9).

For the practical application of SSEs in SSLMBs, the soft-package device is more persuasive than coin-type cells. Figure 4E schematically illustrates the interior structure of the soft-package all-solid-state Li/SSEs/LFP batteries. Figures 4F and 4G exhibit a representative as-assembled soft-package Li/SSEs/LFP battery with an open-circuit voltage (OCV) of 3.5 V and a couple of CV peaks is similar to that of coin-typed cells. After charging, this soft-package battery can fully light up a light-emitting-diode (LED) with bright green color (Figure 4H1). Subsequently, regardless of whether bent 90° (Figure 4H2), 180° (Figure 4H3) or folded twice (Figure 4H4), the soft-package battery can effectively empower the green LED. In another set, although the soft-package battery is in turn cut off one-fifth (Figure 4H5), one-half (Figure 4H6) and three quarters (Figure 4H7) under atmospheric environment, it could still power the green LED efficiently. Even when the center of soft-package cell is perforated, the green LED is abidingly illuminated (Figure 4H8). Obviously, this all-solid-state soft-package battery exhibits no abnormalities such as combustion or explosion, which could forcefully illuminate the excellent security and reliability of our 3D F-LLTO@PEO SSEs for commercial application in all-solid-state soft-package LMBs.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Disclosing physicochemical protection mechanism of 3D F-LLTO@PEO SSE
ce:section.ce:para:
The physicochemical protection strategy was used to endow 3D F-LLTO@PEO-based LMBs with outstanding rate capability, excellent cycling stability, and high security. Then this two-tier effect and its mechanism would be systematically disclosed. According to the molecular orbital theory, once the F-LLTO SSEs contact with Li anode, a thermodynamically unstable SEI layer is inevitably constituted at the interface between the electrode and the electrolyte. 45 As the electrochemical reaction process continues, the unstable SEI membrane would be crushed, leading to the growth of lithium dendrites, as illustrated in the step I of Figure 5A. Until the lithium dendrites grow to a certain extent, they would reach the 3D network skeleton of F-LLTO@PEO. At this point, the physical protection from the 3D network skeleton and the chemical protection from fluorine atoms will play a dual role in inhibiting the fierce lithium dendrite growth, 46
,
47 as vividly shown in step II of Figure 5A. This phenomenon can be distinctly explained through a series of XPS, Raman, and SEM characterizations.

Ex-situ XPS is performed with cycled SSEs after 1000 h at 0.1 mA cm−2. As shown in Figures 5B and 5C, the peak at 684 eV in F 1 s spectra from XPS implies that a LiF-rich SEI layer forms between the SSE and Li anode after cycling. The superior ionic conductivity and mechanical strength is not only beneficial for high-rate LMBs, but also facilitates stable lithium deposition and thus shields the Li anode from further reaction with the electrolytes. 44
,
48 Encouragingly, ex-situ Raman spectra of SSEs and Li anode (Figures 5D and 5E) also verify the presence of new chemical species. A small shoulder peak located at 605 cm−1 from both the SSEs and Li anode is assigned to LiF. 49 While the peaks at 920 cm−1 and 1250 cm−1 could be indexed to the LLTO@PEO composite. The gradually increased peak intensities of the cycled Li anode indicates the uniform deposition of Li+ between the 3D F-LLTO@PEO SSEs and the Li anode. 50 In Figure S24A, there are few lithium dendrites emerged on the surface of the Li metallic anode after cycling with the 3D F-LTTO@PEO SSEs. For the F-free SSE-based battery, this physically dendrite-suppressed function of 3D LLTO networks and the flexible PEO matrix is severely insufficient. With the continuous Li+ plating/stripping, the propagation and growth of Li dendrites occur on the Li surface due to the formation of an inhomogeneous SEI layer (Figure S24B). Therefore, 3D F-LTTO@PEO SSEs can effectively restrain the growth of Li dendrites and regulate distinctly uniform Li deposition.

Finally, Li metal will be uniformly covered on the 3D network skeleton and an artificially enhanced LiF-rich SEI layer will be established between the electrolyte and electrodes, 51 as revealed in step III of Figure 5A. Ex-situ SEM are carried out with cycled Li foil after 100 cycles. As expected, it prefers smooth to rough morphology (as shown in Figures 5F−5I), demonstrating the absence of robust Li dendrites. Further, the more extensive thickness variation of the cycled Li anode in the F-free-LLTO system than the F-LLTO system also indicates the homogeneous lithium deposition. These results unambiguously imply that a physicochemically dendrite-suppressed effect of 3D F-LTTO@PEO occurs for high-rate LMBs.

In conclusion, we designed the 3D in situ-fluorinated F-LLTO@PEO SSEs for the synergistically enhanced physicochemical interface stability. This physicochemically dendrite-suppressed strategy could significantly enhance the Li+ transporting and eliminate the risk of Li dendrites, resulting in an ultrahigh room-temperature ionic conductivity (5 × 10−4 S cm−1), advanced mechanical strength and outstanding electrochemical stability (> 1000 h under 0.1 mA cm−2) of 3D F-LLTO@PEO SSE. Based on this electrolyte, all-solid-state LMBs exhibit extraordinary rate-performance of 95 mAh g−1 @ 5C and decent cycling stability over 85% after 100 cycles at 90°C. Particularly, this synergistically physicochemical effect was comprehensively proved to be originated from the physical protection of the 3D nanofibers network and the chemical protection of the LiF-rich SEI layer. Evidently, this physicochemically dendrite-suppressed strategy will guide successful accomplishment of dendrite-free high-performance all-solid-state LMBs
Further information and requests for resources and reagents should be directed to and will be fulfilled by the Lead Contact, Prof. Weiqing Yang (wqyang@swjtu.edu.cn).

F-LLTO precursor, Lithium carbonate (Li2CO3, > 99.99% Aladdin), Lanthanum oxide (La2O, > 99.99% Aladdin), Tetrabutyl titanate (TBOT, > 99.9% Aladdin), Lithium fluoride (LiF, > 99.99% Aladdin), Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, average = 1,200,000, Sigma-Aldrich), Poly (ethylene oxide) (PEO, average = 600,000, Sigma-Aldrich), Lithium perchlorate (LiClO4, Aladdin) were used and stored in a Ar glove box with measured levels of oxygen and water contents below 0.1 ppm. Battery grade Lithium iron phosphate (LiFePO4, LFP), N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP), N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF), lithium foil and Super P (C65) was purchased from Saibo electrochemical Co., Ltd with further dehydration. The LFP electrode contains 60 wt% active material, 30 wt% SSE binder and 10 wt% conductive carbon coated on an aluminum (Al) current collector foil with an active material mass loading of 4 mg cm−2. The electrodes were punched into disks with a diameter of 8 mm and dried under vacuum for 12 h at 120°C before use.

The precursor 3D F-LLTO (Li0.33La0.557TiO3-yFy, in which y is about 0.045) were first synthesized via an electrospinning method. Stoichiometric amounts of Li2CO3, La2O, LiF and Ti(O4CH9)4 were dissolved in DMF with acetic acid and acetylacetone. Specifically, 0.163 g Li2CO3, 1.136 g La2O3, 0.0649 g LiF and 4.259 g Ti(O4CH9)4 are weighted according to the stoichiometric ratio with excess 15 wt% Li2CO3 (0.0245 g) to compensate for Li loss during heat treatment. Dimethylformamide (5 mL), acetic acid (2 mL) and acetylacetone (2 mL) are mixed in a 5:2:2 volume ratio to prepare a solvent. The mixture is dissolved in the solvent and vigorously stirred for 12 h at 40°C until a homogeneous solution is obtained. Then, an appropriate amount of poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP, Mw = 1300000) is added into the solution to from a yellow, transport and viscous F-LLTO precursor. The precursor was loaded into a 10 mL plastic capillary and spilled from a stainless-steel needle to a rolling collector (1500 rpm) covered with aluminum foil under 1 kV cm−1. A nanofiber network with a thickness of ∼100 μm should be peeled off after 3 h spinning. To form a uniform network, the salt concentration, viscosity, and defoaming time of the precursor, voltage, and distance between the needle and collector need to be carefully controlled. Then the F-LLTO 3D skeleton are acquired by calcining the as-spun fibers at 850°C for 2 h in air with a heating rate of 1°C min−1. To prepare the 3D F-LLTO@PEO SSE, the PEO and LiClO4 (EO:Li = 16) were dissolved into acetonitrile. The solutions were gradually dripped onto the 3D F-LLTO disk and the samples were dried at room temperature (RT) for 12 h in a Ar glove box. Next, the membranes were sandwiched between two PTFE plates, hot-pressed at 80°C under 10 MPa for 30 min and quenched in liquid N2. Finally, a flexible membrane with a thickness of 150∼200 μm was obtained and then stored in a vacuum oven at RT for further use.

Morphology characterizations were conducted by using SEM (JEOL 7800F, 5 kV) as well as EDS microanalysis. A JEOL JEM-2100F microscope operated at 200 kV in a scanning mode with a nominal analytical beam size of 0.5 nm was used to conduct the TEM, high-resolution TEM investigations and TEM mapping. Crystal structures of samples were performed by power X-ray diffraction (PANalytical X’pert, Cu Ka, 0.154056 nm) and high-resolution neutron diffraction (HRND, AE01020026). The XRD and HRND were prepared by means of grinding and flattening the powders or membranes on small slides. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB Xi+) was used to determine the elementary composition of SEI layer before and after cycling. Raman spectroscopic analysis was conducted with a HORIBA Jobin-Yvon XploRA ONE contocal Raman microscope with 532 nm laser and an air-cooled CCD dector.

The electrochemical properties of the samples were studied using CR2025-type coin cells and pouch cells. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) and cyclic voltammetry (CV) was conducted with stainless steel served as working electrode and Li metal foil as both counter and reference electrodes. The LSV and CV measurements were carried out on an electrochemical workstation (CHI660E, Shanghai, China) with a scan rate of 10 mV and 0.1 mV from open-circuit voltage to 6 V versus Li+/Li, respectively. The electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) of the symmetric cells and full cells were collected on an electrochemical workstation (CHI660E, Shanghai, China) in the range of 1 Hz−1 MHz with a potential amplitude of 10 mV. Galvanostatic charge-discharge cycles were carried out by a computer-controlled battery tester system (Neware CT2100) at rate of 0.1C, 0.2C, 0.5C, 1C, 2C, 3C and 5C in the voltage range of 2.5−4.3 V at 90°C. Lithium plating/stripping experiment with a symmetric Li |F-LLTO| Li cell as a function of time cycled at a current density of 0.1, 0.5 and 1 mA cm−2 at 90°C.

The density functional theory calculations were performed with the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP). The functional of choice was Perdew-Burke-Ernzerh and the van der Waals contributions were obtained through the DFT-D2 method 48 . This setup has been proven to predict the crystal structure and binding energy of fluoridated LLTO. The inner electrons were represented by projector-augmented wave pseudopotentials and the monoelectronic states were expanded in plane waves with a kinetic energy cutoff of 450 eV. The crystal of F-LLTO were modeled by a five-layers slab and at least p (2 × 2) supercells, where the two uppermost layers were fully relaxed and the rest fixed to the bulk distances. The substantial number of F atoms for O atoms are determined through EDS results. In the energy calculations, the Brillouin zone was sampled by a Γ-centered k points mesh from the Monkhorst-Pack method, and the k point samplings were denser than 30 Å−1. In all cases, the nature of the saddle points was assessed by the diagonalization of the numerical Hessian generated by 0.02 Å displacements for each coordinate. All TS structures have a single imaginary frequency. In all cases the optimization thresholds were 10−5 eV and 0.02 eV Å−1 for electronic and ionic relaxations, respectively.
